XùëãX-Secure TùëáT-Private Federated Submodel Learning with Elastic Dropout Resilience

Zhuqing Jia and Syed A. Jafar
Abstract

Motivated by recent interest in federated submodel learning, this work explores the fundamental problem of privately reading from and writing to a database comprised of KùêæK files (submodels) that are stored across NùëÅN distributed servers according to an XùëãX-secure threshold secret sharing scheme. One after another, various users wish to retrieve their desired file, locally process the information and then update the file in the distributed database while keeping the identity of their desired file private from any set of up to TùëáT colluding servers. The availability of servers changes over time, so elastic dropout resilience is required. The main contribution of this work is an adaptive scheme, called ACSA-RW, that takes advantage of all currently available servers to reduce its communication costs, fully updates the database after each write operation even though the database is only partially accessible due to server dropouts, and ensures a memoryless operation of the network in the sense that the storage structure is preserved and future users may remain oblivious of the past history of server dropouts. The ACSA-RW construction builds upon cross-subspace alignment (CSA) codes that were originally introduced for XùëãX-secure TùëáT-private information retrieval and have been shown to be natural solutions for secure distributed matrix multiplication problems. ACSA-RW achieves the desired private read and write functionality with elastic dropout resilience, matches the best results for private-read from PIR literature, improves significantly upon available baselines for private-write, reveals a striking symmetry between upload and download costs, and exploits redundant storage dimensions to accommodate arbitrary read and write dropout servers up to certain threshold values. It also answers in the affirmative an open question by Kairouz et al. by exploiting synergistic gains from the joint design of private read and write operations.

I Introduction

The rise of machine learning is marked by fundamental tradeoffs between competing concerns. Central to this work are 1) the need for abundant training data, 2) the need for privacy, and 3) the need for low communication cost. Federated learning [McMahan_FL, FLsurvey1, FLsurvey2, FLsurvey3] is a distributed machine learning paradigm that addresses the first two concerns by allowing distributed users/clients (e.g., mobile phones) to collaboratively train a shared model that is stored in a cluster of databases/servers (cloud) while keeping their training data private. The users retrieve the current model, train the model locally with their own training data, and then aggregate the modifications as focused updates. Thus, federated learning allows utilization of abundant training data while preserving its privacy. However, this incurs higher communication cost as each update involves communication of all model parameters.

Communicating the full model may be unnecessary for large scale machine learning tasks where each user‚Äôs local data is primarily relevant to a small part of the overall model. Federated Submodel Learning (FSL) [SFSM] builds on this observation by partitioning the model into multiple submodels and allowing users to selectively train and update the submodels that are most relevant to their local view. This is the case, for example, in the binary relevance method for multi-label classification[Classifier_Read, Binary_Luaces], which independently trains a series of binary classifiers (viewed as submodels), one for each label. Given a sample to be predicted, the compound model predicts all labels for which the respective classifiers yield a positive result.

What makes federated submodel learning challenging is the privacy constraint. The identity of the submodel that is being retrieved and updated by a user must remain private. Prior works [SFSM, FLDP1, FLDP2, FLDP3, FLDP4] that assume centralized storage of all submodels are generally able to provide relatively weaker privacy guarantees such as plausible deniability through differential privacy mechanisms that perturb the data and rely on secure inter-user peer-to-peer communication for secure aggregation. On the other hand, it is noted recently by Kim and Lee in [Kim_Lee_FSL] that if the servers that store the submodels are distributed, then stronger information theoretic guarantees such111By perfect privacy we mean that absolutely no information is leaked about the identity of a user‚Äôs desired submodel to any set of colluding servers up to a target threshold. as ‚Äúperfect privacy‚Äù may be attainable, without the need for user-to-user communication. Indeed, in this work we focus on this setting of distributed servers and perfect privacy. The challenge of federated submodel learning in this setting centers around three key questions.

  1. Q1

    Private Read: How can a user efficiently retrieve the desired submodel from the distributed servers without revealing which submodel is being retrieved?

  2. Q2

    Private Write: How can a user efficiently update the desired submodel to the distributed servers without revealing which submodel is being updated?

  3. Q3

    Synergy of Private Read-Write: Are there synergistic gains in the joint design of retrieval and update operations, and if so, then how to exploit these synergies?

The significance of these fundamental questions goes well beyond federated submodel learning. As recognized by [SFSM] the private read question (Q1) by itself is equivalent to the problem of Private Information Retrieval (PIR) [PIRfirst, PIRfirstjournal], which has recently been studied extensively from an information theoretic perspective [Sun_Jafar_PIR, Sun_Jafar_TPIR, Sun_Jafar_SPIR, Wang_Sun_Skoglund, Wang_Skoglund_SPIREve, Banawan_Ulukus_BPIR, Tajeddine_Gnilke_Karpuk_Hollanti, Wang_Sun_Skoglund_BSPIR, Tajeddine_Gnilke_Karpuk, Wang_Skoglund_TSPIR, FREIJ_HOLLANTI, Sun_Jafar_MDSTPIR, Jia_Jafar_MDSXSTPIR, Zhou_Tian_Sun_Liu_Min_Size, Yang_Shin_Lee, Jia_Sun_Jafar_XSTPIR, Banawab_Arasli_Wei_Ulukus_Heterogeneous, Wei_Arasli_Banawan_Ulukus_Decentralized, Attia_Kumar_Tandon, Wei_Banawan_Ulukus, Tandon_CachePIR, Li_Gastpar_SSMUPIR, Wei_Banawan_Ulukus_Side, Chen_Wang_Jafar_Side, Sun_Jafar_MPIR, Yao_Liu_Kang_Multiround, Banawan_Ulukus_MPIR, Shariatpanahi_Siavoshani_Maddah, Wang_Banawan_Ulukus_PSI, Tian_Sun_Chen_Upload, Sun_Jafar_PC, Mirmohseni_Maddah, Chen_Wang_Jafar_Search, Jia_Jafar_GXSTPIR, Lu_Jia_Jafar_DBTPIR]. Much less is known about Q2 and Q3, i.e., the fundamental limits of private-write, and joint read-write solutions from the information theoretic perspective. Notably, Q3 has also been highlighted previously as an open problem by Kairouz et al in [FLsurvey1].

The problem of privately reading and writing data from a distributed memory falls under the larger umbrella of Distributed Oblivious RAM (DORAM)[Lu_DORAM] primitives in theoretical computer science and cryptography. With a few limited exceptions (e.g., a specialized 444-server construction in [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub] that allows information theoretic privacy), prior studies of DORAM generally take a cryptographic perspective, e.g., privacy is guaranteed subject to computational hardness assumptions, and the number of memory blocks is assumed to be much larger than the size of each block. In contrast, the focus of this work is on Q2 and Q3 under the stronger notion of information theoretic privacy. Furthermore, because our motivation comes from federated submodel learning, the size of a submodel is assumed to be significantly larger than the number of submodels (see motivating examples in [SFSM] and Section III-A9). Indeed, this is a pervasive assumption in the growing body of literature on information theoretic PIR[Sun_Jafar_PIR, Sun_Jafar_TPIR, Sun_Jafar_SPIR, Wang_Sun_Skoglund, Wang_Skoglund_SPIREve, Banawan_Ulukus_BPIR, Tajeddine_Gnilke_Karpuk_Hollanti, Wang_Sun_Skoglund_BSPIR, Tajeddine_Gnilke_Karpuk, Wang_Skoglund_TSPIR, FREIJ_HOLLANTI, Sun_Jafar_MDSTPIR, Jia_Jafar_MDSXSTPIR, Zhou_Tian_Sun_Liu_Min_Size, Yang_Shin_Lee, Jia_Sun_Jafar_XSTPIR, Banawab_Arasli_Wei_Ulukus_Heterogeneous, Wei_Arasli_Banawan_Ulukus_Decentralized, Attia_Kumar_Tandon, Wei_Banawan_Ulukus, Tandon_CachePIR, Li_Gastpar_SSMUPIR, Wei_Banawan_Ulukus_Side, Chen_Wang_Jafar_Side, Sun_Jafar_MPIR, Yao_Liu_Kang_Multiround, Banawan_Ulukus_MPIR, Shariatpanahi_Siavoshani_Maddah, Wang_Banawan_Ulukus_PSI, Tian_Sun_Chen_Upload, Sun_Jafar_PC, Mirmohseni_Maddah, Chen_Wang_Jafar_Search, Jia_Jafar_GXSTPIR, Lu_Jia_Jafar_DBTPIR]. In a broad sense, our problem formulation in this paper is motivated by applications of (information theoretic) PIR that also require private writes. There is no shortage of such applications, e.g., a distributed database of medical records that not only allows a physician to privately download the desired record (private read) but also to update the record with new information (private write), or a banking service that would similarly allow private reads and writes of financial records from authorized entities. Essentially, while FSL serves as our nominal application of interest based on prior works that motivated this effort, our problem formulation is broad enough to capture various distributed file systems that enable the users to read and write files without revealing the identity of the target file. The files are viewed as submodels, and the assumption that the size of the file is significantly larger than the number of the files captures the nature of file systems that are most relevant to this work.

Overview: We consider the federated submodel learning setting where the global model is partitioned into KùêæK submodels, and stored among NùëÅN distributed servers according to an XùëãX-secure threshold secret sharing scheme, i.e., any set of up to XùëãX colluding servers can learn nothing about the stored models, while the full model can be recovered from the data stored by any X+KcfragmentsXKùëêX+K_{c} servers. One at a time, users update the submodel most relevant to their local training data. The updates must be TùëáT-private, i.e., any set of up to TùëáT colluding servers must not learn anything about which submodel is being updated. The contents of the updates must be XŒîfragmentsXŒîX_{\Delta}-secure, i.e., any set of up to XŒîfragmentsXŒîX_{\Delta} colluding servers must learn nothing about the contents of the submodel updates. The size of a submodel is significantly larger than the number of submodels, which is significantly larger than 111, i.e., L‚â´K‚â´1fragmentsLmuch-greater-thanKmuch-greater-than1L\gg K\gg 1 where LùêøL is the size of a submodel and KùêæK is the number of submodels. Due to uncertainties of the servers‚Äô I/O states, link states, etc., an important concern in distributed systems is to allow resilience against servers that may temporarily drop out [Kadhe_Fastsecagg, Lee_Lam_Pedarsani, Tandon_Lei_Dimakis_Karampatziakis, Chen_Wang_Charles_Papailiopoulos, Sohn_Han_Choi_Moon]. To this end, we assume that at each time t,t‚àà‚Ñïfragmentst,tNt,t\in\mathbb{N}, a subset of servers may be unavailable. These unavailable servers are referred to as read-dropout servers or write-dropout servers depending on whether the user intends to perform the private read or the private write operation. Since the set of dropout servers changes over time, and is assumed to be known to the user, the private read and write schemes must adapt to the set of currently available servers. Note that this is different from the problem of stragglers in massive distributed computing applications where the set of responsive servers is not known in advance, because servers may become unavailable during the lengthy time interval required for their local computations. Since our focus is not on massive computing applications, the server side processing needed for private read and write is not as time-consuming. So the availabilities, which are determined in advance by the user before initiating the read or write operation, e.g., by pinging the servers, are not expected to change during the read or write operation. We do allow the server availabilities to change between the read and write operations due to the delay introduced by the intermediate processing that is needed at the user to generate his updated submodel. A somewhat surprising aspect of private write with unavailable servers is that even though the data at the unavailable servers cannot be updated, the collective storage at all servers (including the unavailable ones) must represent the updated models. The redundancy in coded storage and the XùëãX-security constraints which require that the stored information at any XùëãX servers is independent of the data, are essential in this regard.

Since the private-read problem (Q1) is essentially a form of PIR, our starting point is the XùëãX-secure TùëáT-private information retrieval scheme (XSTPIR) of [Jia_Sun_Jafar_XSTPIR]. In particular, we build on the idea of cross-subspace alignment (CSA) from [Jia_Sun_Jafar_XSTPIR], and introduce a new private read-write scheme, called Adaptive CSA-RW (ACSA-RW) as an answer to Q1 and Q2. To our knowledge ACSA-RW is the first communication-efficient private federated submodel learning scheme that achieves information-theoretically perfect privacy. ACSA-RW also answers Q3 in the affirmative as it exploits query structure from the private-read operation to reduce the communication cost for the private-write operation. The evidence of synergistic gain in ACSA-RW from a joint design of submodel retrieval and submodel aggregation addresses the corresponding open problem highlighted in Section 4.4.4 of [FLsurvey1]. The observation that the ACSA-RW scheme takes advantage of storage redundancy for private read and private write is indicative of fundamental tradeoffs between download cost, upload cost, data security level, and storage redundancy for security and recoverability. In particular, the storage redundancy for XùëãX-security is exploited by private write, while the storage redundancy for robust recoverability is used for private read (see Theorem 1 and Section III-A1 for details). It is also remarkable that the ACSA-RW scheme requires absolutely no user-user communication, even though the server states change over time and the read-write operations are adaptive. In other words, a user is not required to be aware of the history of previous updates and the previous availability states of the servers (see Section III-A6 for details). The download cost and the upload cost achieved by each user is an increasing function of the number of unavailable servers at the time. When more servers are available, the download cost and the upload costs are reduced, which provides elastic dropout resilience (see Theorem 1). To this end, the ACSA-RW scheme uses adaptive MDS-coded answer strings. This idea originates from CSA code constructions for the problem of coded distributed batch computation[Jia_Jafar_CDBC]. In terms of comparisons against available baselines, we note (see Section III-A7) that ACSA-RW improves significantly in both the communication efficiency and the level of privacy compared to [Kim_Lee_FSL]. In fact, ACSA-RW achieves asymptotically optimal download cost when X‚â•XŒî+TfragmentsXXŒîTX\geq X_{\Delta}+T, and is order-wise optimal in terms of the upload cost. Compared with the 444 server construction of information theoretic DORAM in [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub], (where X=1,T=1,XŒî=0,N=4fragmentsX1,T1,XŒî0,N4X=1,T=1,X_{\Delta}=0,N=4) ACSA-RW has better communication efficiency (the assumption of L‚â´KfragmentsLmuch-greater-thanKL\gg K is important in this regard). For example, as the ratio L/KfragmentsLKL/K approaches infinity, ACSA-RW achieves total communication cost (i.e., the summation of the download cost and the upload cost, normalized by the submodel size) of 666, versus the communication cost of 888 achieved by the construction in [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub].

The storage at the NùëÅN servers is formalized according to a threshold secret sharing scheme. Specifically, the storage at any set of up to XùëãX colluding servers must reveal nothing about the submodels. Formally,

where for all n‚àà[N]fragmentsn[N]n\in[N], we define ùêín‚àí1=√òfragmentsSùëõfragments1√ò\mathbf{S}_{n}^{-1}=\O. Note that ùíµSfragmentsZùëÜ\mathcal{Z}_{S} is the private randomness used by the secret sharing scheme that implements XùëãX-secure storage across the NùëÅN servers.

There is a subtle difference in the security constraint that we impose on the storage, and the previously specified security and privacy constraints on updates and queries. To appreciate this difference let us make a distinction between the notions of an internal adversary and an external adversary. We say that a set of colluding servers forms an internal adversary if those colluding servers have access to not only their current storage, but also their entire history of previous stored values and queries. Essentially the internal adversary setting represents a greater security threat because the servers themselves are dishonest and surreptitiously keep records of all their history in an attempt to learn from it. In contrast, we say that a set of colluding servers forms an external adversary if those colluding servers have access to only their current storage, but not to other historical information. Essentially, this represents an external adversary who is able to steal the current information from honest servers who do not keep records of their historical information. Clearly, an external adversary is weaker than an internal adversary. Now let us note that while the TùëáT-private queries and the XŒîfragmentsXŒîX_{\Delta}-secure updates are protected against internal adversaries, the XùëãX-secure storage is only protected against external adversaries. This is mainly because we will generally assume X>max(XŒî,T)fragmentsX(XŒî,T)X>\max(X_{\Delta},T), i.e., a higher security threshold for storage, than for updates and queries. Note that once the number of compromised servers exceeds max(XŒî,T)fragments(XŒî,T)\max(X_{\Delta},T), the security of updates and the privacy of queries is no longer guaranteed. In such settings the security of storage is still guaranteed, albeit in a weaker sense (against external adversaries). On the other hand if the number of compromised servers is small enough, then indeed secure storage may be guaranteed in a stronger sense, even against internal adversaries. We refer the reader to Remark LABEL:remark:extintadv for further insight into this aspect.

The independence among various quantities of interest is specified for all t‚àà‚ÑïfragmentstNt\in\mathbb{N} as follows.

H((ùêñk(0))k‚àà[K],(ùö´œÑ)œÑ‚àà[t],(Œ∏œÑ)œÑ‚àà[t],(ùíµU(œÑ))œÑ‚àà[t],ùíµS)fragmentsH((Wùëòfragments(0))fragmentsk[K],(Œîùúè)fragmentsœÑ[t],(Œ∏ùúè)fragmentsœÑ[t],(Zùëàfragments(œÑ))fragmentsœÑ[t],ZùëÜ)\displaystyle H\left(\left(\mathbf{W}_{k}^{(0)}\right)_{k\in[K]},\left(\mathbf{\Delta}_{\tau}\right)_{\tau\in[t]},\left(\theta_{\tau}\right)_{\tau\in[t]},\left(\mathcal{Z}_{U}^{(\tau)}\right)_{\tau\in[t]},\mathcal{Z}_{S}\right)
=H((ùêñk(0))k‚àà[K])+H((ùö´œÑ)œÑ‚àà[t])+H((Œ∏œÑ)œÑ‚àà[t])+H((ùíµU(œÑ))œÑ‚àà[t])+H(ùíµS).fragmentsH((Wùëòfragments(0))fragmentsk[K])H((Œîùúè)fragmentsœÑ[t])H((Œ∏ùúè)fragmentsœÑ[t])H((Zùëàfragments(œÑ))fragmentsœÑ[t])H(ZùëÜ).\displaystyle=H\left(\left(\mathbf{W}_{k}^{(0)}\right)_{k\in[K]}\right)+H\left(\left(\mathbf{\Delta}_{\tau}\right)_{\tau\in[t]}\right)+H\left(\left(\theta_{\tau}\right)_{\tau\in[t]}\right)+H\left(\left(\mathcal{Z}_{U}^{(\tau)}\right)_{\tau\in[t]}\right)+H(\mathcal{Z}_{S}). (15)

To evaluate the performance of a robust XSTPFSL scheme, we consider the following metrics. The first two metrics focus on communication cost. For t‚àà‚ÑïfragmentstNt\in\mathbb{N}, the download cost DtfragmentsDùë°D_{t} is the expected (over all realizations of queries) number of qùëûq-ary symbols downloaded by User tùë°t, normalized by LùêøL. The upload cost UtfragmentsUùë°U_{t} is the expected number of qùëûq-ary symbols uploaded by User tùë°t, also normalized by LùêøL. The next metric focuses on storage efficiency. For t‚àà‚Ñ§‚àófragmentstZt\in\mathbb{Z}^{*}, the storage efficiency is defined as the ratio of the total data content to the total storage resources consumed by a scheme, i.e., Œ∑(t)=KL‚àën‚àà[N]H(Sn(t))fragmentsŒ∑fragments(t)fragmentsKLfragmentsfragmentsn[N]H(Sùëõfragments(t))\eta^{(t)}=\frac{KL}{\sum_{n\in[N]}H\left(S_{n}^{(t)}\right)}. If Œ∑(t)fragmentsŒ∑fragments(t)\eta^{(t)} takes the same value for all t‚àà‚Ñ§‚àófragmentstZt\in\mathbb{Z}^{*}, we use the compact notation Œ∑ùúÇ\eta instead.

III Main Result: The ACSA-RW Scheme for Private Read/Write

The main contribution of this work is the ACSA-RW scheme, which allows private read and private write from NùëÅN distributed servers according to the problem statement provided in Section II. The scheme achieves storage efficiency Kc/NfragmentsKùëêNK_{c}/N, i.e., it uses a total storage of (KLN/Kc)log2qfragments(KLNKùëê)2q(KLN/K_{c})\log_{2}q bits across NùëÅN servers in order to store the KLlog2qfragmentsKL2qKL\log_{2}q bits of actual data, where Kc‚àà‚ÑïfragmentsKùëêNK_{c}\in\mathbb{N}, and allows arbitrary read-dropouts and write-dropouts as long as the number of dropout servers is less than the corresponding threshold values. The thresholds are defined below and their relationship to redundant storage dimensions is explained in Section III-A1.

Read-dropout threshold: SrthreshfragmentsSùëüthresh\displaystyle S_{r}^{\text{thresh}} ‚âúN‚àí(Kc+X+T‚àí1).fragments‚âúN(KùëêXT1).\displaystyle\triangleq N-(K_{c}+X+T-1). (16)
Write-dropout threshold: SwthreshfragmentsSùë§thresh\displaystyle S_{w}^{\text{thresh}} ‚âúX‚àí(XŒî+T‚àí1).fragments‚âúX(XŒîT1).\displaystyle\triangleq X-(X_{\Delta}+T-1). (17)

It is worth emphasizing that the ACSA-RW scheme does not just tolerate dropout servers, it adapts (hence the elastic resilience) to the number of available servers so as to reduce its communication cost. The elasticity would be straightforward if the only concern was the private-read operation because known PIR schemes can be adapted to the number of available servers. What makes the elasticity requirement non-trivial is that the scheme must accommodate both private read and private write. The private-write requirements are particularly intriguing, almost paradoxical in that the coded storage across all NùëÅN servers needs to be updated to be consistent with the new submodels, even though some of those servers (the write-dropout servers) are unavailable, so their stored information cannot be changed. Furthermore, as server states continue to change over time, future updates need no knowledge of prior dropout histories. Also of interest are the tradeoffs between storage redundancy and the resources needed for private-read and private-write functionalities. Because many of these aspects become more intuitively transparent when L‚â´K‚â´1fragmentsLmuch-greater-thanKmuch-greater-than1L\gg K\gg 1, the asymptotic setting is used to present the main result in Theorem 1. In particular, by suppressing minor terms (which can be found in the full description of the scheme), the asymptotic setting reveals an elegant symmetry between the upload and download costs. The remainder of this section is devoted to stating and then understanding the implications of Theorem 1. The scheme itself is presented in the form of the proof of Theorem 1 in Section IV.

Theorem 1.

In the limit L/K‚Üí‚àûfragmentsLK‚ÜíL/K\rightarrow\infty, for all t‚àà‚ÑïfragmentstNt\in\mathbb{N} the ACSA-RW scheme achieves the following download, upload cost pair (Dt,Ut)fragments(Dùë°,Uùë°)(D_{t},U_{t}) and storage efficiency Œ∑ùúÇ\eta:

(Dt,Ut)fragments(Dùë°,Uùë°)\displaystyle(D_{t},U_{t}) =(N‚àí|ùíÆr(t)|Srthresh‚àí|ùíÆr(t)|,N‚àí|ùíÆw(t)|Swthresh‚àí|ùíÆw(t)|),fragments(fragmentsN|Sùëüfragments(t)|fragmentsSùëüthresh|Sùëüfragments(t)|,fragmentsN|Sùë§fragments(t)|fragmentsSùë§thresh|Sùë§fragments(t)|),\displaystyle=\left(\frac{N-|\mathcal{S}_{r}^{(t)}|}{S_{r}^{\text{thresh}}-|\mathcal{S}_{r}^{(t)}|},~{}\frac{N-|\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}|}{S_{w}^{\text{thresh}}-|\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}|}\right), Œ∑=KcN,fragmentsŒ∑fragmentsKùëêùëÅ,\displaystyle\eta=\frac{K_{c}}{N}, (18)

for any Kc‚àà‚ÑïfragmentsKùëêNK_{c}\in\mathbb{N} such that |ùíÆr(t)|<Srthreshfragments|Sùëüfragments(t)|Sùëüthresh|\mathcal{S}_{r}^{(t)}|<S_{r}^{\text{thresh}}, |ùíÆw(t)|<Swthreshfragments|Sùë§fragments(t)|Sùë§thresh|\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}|<S_{w}^{\text{thresh}}, and the field size q‚â•N+max{Srthresh,Swthresh,Kc}fragmentsqN{Sùëüthresh,Sùë§thresh,Kùëê}q\geq N+\max\left\{S_{r}^{\text{thresh}},S_{w}^{\text{thresh}},K_{c}\right\}.

III-A Observations

III-A1 Storage Redundancy and Private Read/Write Thresholds

The relationship between redundant storage dimensions and the private read/write thresholds is conceptually illustrated in Figure 2.

The total storage utilized by the ACSA-RW scheme across NùëÅN servers is represented as the overall NùëÅN dimensional space in Figure 2. Out of this, the actual data occupies only KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c} dimensions, which is why the storage efficiency of ACSA-RW is Kc/NfragmentsKùëêNK_{c}/N. Because the storage must be XùëãX-secure, i.e., any set of up to XùëãX colluding servers cannot learn anything about the data, it follows that out of the NùëÅN dimensions of storage space, XùëãX dimensions are occupied by information that is independent of the actual data. The storage redundancy represented by these XùëãX dimensions will be essential to enable the private-write functionality. But first let us consider the private-read operation for which we have a number of prior results on PIR as baselines for validating our intuition. From Figure 2 we note that outside the XùëãX dimensions of redundancy that was introduced due to data-security, the TùëáT-privacy constraint adds a storage redundancy of another T‚àí1fragmentsT1T-1 dimensions that is shown in red. To understand this, compare the asymptotic (large KùêæK) capacity of MDS-PIR [Banawan_Ulukus]: CMDS-PIR=1‚àíKc/NfragmentsCMDS-PIR1KùëêNC_{\text{MDS-PIR}}=1-K_{c}/N with the (conjectured) asymptotic capacity of MDS-TPIR [FREIJ_HOLLANTI, Sun_Jafar_MDSTPIR]: CMDS-TPIR=1‚àí(Kc+T‚àí1)/NfragmentsCMDS-TPIR1(KùëêT1)NC_{\text{MDS-TPIR}}=1-(K_{c}+T-1)/N. To achieve a non-zero value of the asymptotic capacity, the former requires N>KcfragmentsNKùëêN>K_{c}, but the latter requires N>Kc+T‚àí1fragmentsNKùëêT1N>K_{c}+T-1. Equivalently, the former allows a read-dropout threshold of N‚àíKcfragmentsNKùëêN-K_{c} while the latter allows a read-dropout threshold of N‚àí(Kc+T‚àí1)fragmentsN(KùëêT1)N-(K_{c}+T-1). In fact, going further to the (conjectured) asymptotic capacity of MDS-XSTPIR [Jia_Jafar_MDSXSTPIR], which also includes the XùëãX-security constraint, we note that a non-zero value of capacity requires N>Kc+X+T‚àí1fragmentsNKùëêXT1N>K_{c}+X+T-1. Intuitively, we may interpret this as: the XùëãX-security constraint increases the demands on storage redundancy by XùëãX dimensions and the TùëáT-privacy constraint increases the demands on storage redundancy by another T‚àí1fragmentsT1T-1 dimensions. This is what is represented in Figure 2. Aside from the KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c} dimensions occupied by data, the XùëãX dimensions of redundancy added by the security constraint, and the T‚àí1fragmentsT1T-1 dimensions of redundancy added by the TùëáT-privacy constraint, the remaining dimensions at the right end of the figure are used to accommodate read-dropouts. Indeed, this is what determines the read-dropout threshold, as we note from Figure 2 that N‚àí(X+Kc+(T‚àí1))=SrthreshfragmentsN(XKùëê(T1))SùëüthreshN-(X+K_{c}+(T-1))=S_{r}^{\text{thresh}}. Now consider the private-write operation which is novel and thus lacks comparative baselines. What is remarkable is the synergistic aspect of private-write, that it does not add further redundancy beyond the XùëãX dimensions of storage redundancy already added by the XùëãX-security constraint. Instead, it operates within these XùëãX dimensions to create further sub-partitions. Within these XùëãX dimensions, a total of XŒî+T‚àí1fragmentsXŒîT1X_{\Delta}+T-1 dimensions are used to achieve XŒîfragmentsXŒîX_{\Delta}-secure updates that also preserve TùëáT-privacy, and the remaining dimensions are used to accommodate write-dropout servers, giving us the write-dropout threshold as X‚àí(XŒî+T‚àí1)=SwthreshfragmentsX(XŒîT1)Sùë§threshX-(X_{\Delta}+T-1)=S_{w}^{\text{thresh}}. Remarkably in Figure 2, the (Kc,XŒî,T‚àí1,Swthresh)fragments(Kùëê,XŒî,T1,Sùë§thresh)(K_{c},X_{\Delta},T-1,S_{w}^{\text{thresh}}) partition structure for private-write replicates at a finer level the original (Kc,X,T‚àí1,Srthresh)fragments(Kùëê,X,T1,Sùëüthresh)(K_{c},X,T-1,S_{r}^{\text{thresh}}) partition structure of private-read. Also remarkable is a new constraint introduced by the private-write operation that is not encountered in prior works on PIR ‚Äî the feasibility of ACSA-RW requires X‚â•TfragmentsXTX\geq T. Whether or not this constraint is fundamental in the asymptotic setting of large KùêæK is an open problem for future work.

III-A2 Optimality

Asymptotic (large KùêæK) optimality of ACSA-RW remains an open question in general. Any attempt to resolve this question runs into other prominent open problems in the information-theoretic PIR literature, such as the asymptotic capacity of MDS-TPIR [FREIJ_HOLLANTI, Sun_Jafar_MDSTPIR] and MDS-XSTPIR [Jia_Jafar_MDSXSTPIR] that also remain open. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that Theorem 1 matches or improves upon the best known results in all cases where such results are available. In particular, the private-read phase of ACSA-RW scheme recovers a universally robust XùëãX-secure TùëáT-private information retrieval [Bitar_StairPIR, Jia_Sun_Jafar_XSTPIR] scheme. When Kc=1,X‚â•XŒî+TfragmentsKùëê1,XXŒîTK_{c}=1,X\geq X_{\Delta}+T, it achieves the asymptotic capacity; and when Kc>1,X‚â•XŒî+TfragmentsKùëê1,XXŒîTK_{c}>1,X\geq X_{\Delta}+T, it achieves the conjectured asymptotic capacity [Jia_Jafar_MDSXSTPIR]. While much less is known about optimal private-write schemes, it is clear that ACSA-RW significantly improves upon previous work as explained in Section III-A7. Notably, both upload and download costs are O(1)fragmentsO(1)O(1) in KùêæK, i.e., they do not scale with KùêæK. Thus, at the very least the costs are orderwise optimal. Another interesting point of reference is the best case scenario, where we have no dropout servers, |ùíÆr(t)|=0,|ùíÆw(t)|=0fragments|Sùëüfragments(t)|0,|Sùë§fragments(t)|0|\mathcal{S}_{r}^{(t)}|=0,|\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}|=0. The total communication cost of ACSA-RW in this case, i.e., the sum of upload and download costs, is Dt+Ut=N(1Srthresh+1Swthresh)fragmentsDùë°Uùë°N(1fragmentsSùëüthresh1fragmentsSùë§thresh)D_{t}+U_{t}=N\left(\frac{1}{S_{r}^{\text{thresh}}}+\frac{1}{S_{w}^{\text{thresh}}}\right), which is minimized when Kc=1fragmentsKùëê1K_{c}=1, Srthresh=SwthreshfragmentsSùëüthreshSùë§threshS_{r}^{\text{thresh}}=S_{w}^{\text{thresh}}, and X=(N+XŒî‚àí1)/2fragmentsX(NXŒî1)2X=(N+X_{\Delta}-1)/2. For large NùëÅN, we have Dt+Ut‚âà2+2=4fragmentsDùë°Uùë°224D_{t}+U_{t}\approx 2+2=4, thus in the best case scenario, ACSA-RW is optimal within a factor of 222. Finally, on a speculative note, perhaps the most striking aspect of Theorem 1 is the symmetry between upload and download costs, which (if not coincidental) bodes well for their fundamental significance and information theoretic optimality.

III-A3 The Choice of Parameter KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c}

The choice of the parameter KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c} in ACSA-RW determines the storage efficiency of the scheme, Œ∑=Kc/NfragmentsŒ∑KùëêN\eta=K_{c}/N. At one extreme, we have the smallest possible value of KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c}, i.e., Kc=1fragmentsKùëê1K_{c}=1, which is the least efficient storage setting, indeed the storage efficiency is analogous to replicated storage, each server uses as much storage space as the size of all data (KLlog2qfragmentsKL2qKL\log_{2}q bits). This setting yields the best (smallest) download costs. The other extreme corresponds to the maximum possible value of KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c}, which is obtained as Kc=N‚àí(X+T)fragmentsKùëêN(XT)K_{c}=N-(X+T) because the dropout thresholds cannot be smaller than 111. At this extreme, storage is the most efficient, but there is no storage redundancy left to accommodate any read dropouts, and the download cost of ACSA-RW takes its maximal value, equal to NùëÅN. Remarkably, the upload cost of the private-write operation does not depend on KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c}. However, KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c} is significant for another reason; it determines the access complexity (see Remark LABEL:remark:ac) of both private read and write operations, i.e., the number of bits that are read from or written to by each available server. In particular, the access complexity of each available server in the private read or write phases is at most (KL/Kc)log2qfragments(KLKùëê)2q(KL/K_{c})\log_{2}q, so for example, increasing KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c} from 111 to 222 can reduce the access complexity in half, while simultaneously doubling the storage efficiency.

III-A4 Tradeoff between Upload and Download Costs

The trade-off between the upload cost and the download cost of the ACSA-RW scheme is illustrated via two examples in Figure 3, where we have N=10,XŒî=T=1fragmentsN10,XŒîT1N=10,X_{\Delta}=T=1 for the blue solid curve, and N=10,XŒî=1,T=2fragmentsN10,XŒî1,T2N=10,X_{\Delta}=1,T=2 for the red solid curve. For both examples, we set Kc=1fragmentsKùëê1K_{c}=1 and assume that there are no dropout servers. The trade-off is achieved with various choices of XùëãX. For the example shown in the blue solid curve, we set X=(2,3,4,5,6,7,8)fragmentsX(2,3,4,5,6,7,8)X=(2,3,4,5,6,7,8). For the example in the red solid curve, we set X=(3,4,5,6,7)fragmentsX(3,4,5,6,7)X=(3,4,5,6,7). Note that the most balanced trade-off point is achieved when X=N/2fragmentsXN2X=N/2.

III-A5 Synergistic Gains from Joint Design of Private Read and Write

A notable aspect of the ACSA-RW scheme, which answers in the affirmative an open question raised in Section 4.4.4 of [FLsurvey1], is the synergistic gain from the joint design of the read phase and the write phase. While the details of the scheme are non-trivial and can be found in Section IV, let us provide an intuitive explanation here by ignoring some of the details. As a simplification, let us ignore security constraints and consider the database represented by a vector ùêñ=[W1,W2,‚ãØ,WK]ùñ≥fragmentsW[W1,W2,‚ãØ,Wùêæ]ùñ≥\mathbf{W}=[W_{1},W_{2},\cdots,W_{K}]^{\mathsf{T}} that consists of symbols from the KùêæK submodels. Suppose the user is interested in WŒ∏tfragmentsWfragmentsŒ∏ùë°W_{\theta_{t}} for some index Œ∏t‚àà[K]fragmentsŒ∏ùë°[K]\theta_{t}\in[K] that must be kept private. Note that WŒ∏t=ùêñùñ≥ùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentsWfragmentsŒ∏ùë°Wùñ≥eùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)W_{\theta_{t}}=\mathbf{W}^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}), where ùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}) is the standard basis vector, i.e., the desired symbol is obtained as an inner product of the database vector and the basis vector ùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}). To do this privately, the basis vector is treated by the user as a secret and a linear threshold secret-sharing scheme is used to generate shares that are sent to the servers. The servers return the inner products of the stored data and the secret-shared basis vector, which effectively form the secret shares of the desired inner product. Once the user collects sufficiently many secret shares, (s)he is able to retrieve the desired inner product, and therefore the desired symbol WŒ∏tfragmentsWfragmentsŒ∏ùë°W_{\theta_{t}}. This is the key to the private read-operation. Now during the write phase, the user wishes to update the database to the new state: ùêñ‚Ä≤=[W1,‚ãØ,WŒ∏t‚àí1,WŒ∏t+Œît,WŒ∏t+1‚ãØ,WK]fragmentsW‚Ä≤[W1,‚ãØ,WfragmentsŒ∏ùë°1,WfragmentsŒ∏ùë°Œîùë°,WfragmentsŒ∏ùë°1‚ãØ,Wùêæ]\mathbf{W}^{\prime}=[W_{1},\cdots,W_{\theta_{t}-1},W_{\theta_{t}}+\Delta_{t},W_{\theta_{t}+1}\cdots,W_{K}], which can be expressed as ùêñ‚Ä≤=ùêñ+ŒîtùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentsW‚Ä≤WŒîùë°eùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\mathbf{W}^{\prime}=\mathbf{W}+\Delta_{t}\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}). This can be accomplished by sending the secret-shares of ŒîtùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentsŒîùë°eùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\Delta_{t}\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}) to the NùëÅN servers. The key observation here is the following: since the servers (those that were available during the read phase) have already received secret shares of ùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}), the cost of sending the secret-shares of ŒîtùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentsŒîùë°eùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\Delta_{t}\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}) is significantly reduced. Essentially, it suffices to send secret shares of ŒîtfragmentsŒîùë°\Delta_{t} which can be multiplied with the secret shares of ùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}) to generate secret shares of ŒîtùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentsŒîùë°eùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\Delta_{t}\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}) at the servers. This is much more efficient because ŒîtùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentsŒîùë°eùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)\Delta_{t}\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t}) is a K√ó1fragmentsK1K\times 1 vector, while the dimension of ŒîtfragmentsŒîùë°\Delta_{t} is 111 (scalar), and K‚â´1fragmentsKmuch-greater-than1K\gg 1. This is the intuition behind the synergistic gains from the joint design of private read and write operations that are exploited by ACSA-RW. Note that the servers operate directly on secret shares, as in homomorphic encryption [Duong_Mishra_Yasuda], and that these operations (inner products) are special cases of secure distributed matrix multiplications. Since CSA codes have been shown to be natural solutions for secure distributed matrix multiplications [Jia_Jafar_CDBC], it is intuitively to be expected that CSA schemes should lead to communication-efficient solutions for the private read-write implementation as described above.

III-A6 How to Fully Update a Distributed Database that is only Partially Accessible

A seemingly paradoxical aspect of the write phase of ACSA-RW is that it is able to force the distributed database across all NùëÅN servers to be fully consistent with the updated data, even though the database is only partially accessible due to write-dropout servers. Let us explain the intuition behind this with a toy example888The toy example is not strictly a special case of the ACSA-RW scheme, because the number of servers N=2fragmentsN2N=2 is too small to guarantee any privacy. However, the example serves to demonstrate the key idea. where we have N=2fragmentsN2N=2 servers and X=1fragmentsX1X=1 security level is required. For simplicity we have only one file/submodel, i.e., K=1fragmentsK1K=1, so there are no privacy concerns. The storage at the two servers is S1=W+ZfragmentsS1WZS_{1}=W+Z, S2=ZfragmentsS2ZS_{2}=Z, where WùëäW is the data (submodel) symbol, and ZùëçZ is the random noise symbol used to guarantee the X=1fragmentsX1X=1 security level, i.e., the storage at each server individually reveals nothing about the data WùëäW. The storage can be expressed in the following form.

[S1S2]=[1101]‚èüùêÜ[WZ].fragmentsmatrixfragmentsS1fragmentsS2‚èümatrix1101ùêÜmatrixùëäùëç.\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}S_{1}\\ S_{2}\end{bmatrix}=\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\ 0&1\end{bmatrix}}_{\mathbf{G}}\begin{bmatrix}W\\ Z\end{bmatrix}. (19)

so that ùêÜùêÜ\mathbf{G} is the coding function, and the data can be recovered as S1‚àíS2=WfragmentsS1S2WS_{1}-S_{2}=W.

Now suppose the data WùëäW needs to be updated to the new value W‚Ä≤=W+ŒîfragmentsW‚Ä≤WŒîW^{\prime}=W+\Delta. The updated storage S1‚Ä≤,S2‚Ä≤fragmentsS1‚Ä≤,S2‚Ä≤S_{1}^{\prime},S_{2}^{\prime} should be such that the coding function is unchanged (still the same ùêÜùêÜ\mathbf{G} matrix) and the updated data can similarly be recovered as S1‚Ä≤‚àíS2‚Ä≤=W‚Ä≤fragmentsS1‚Ä≤S2‚Ä≤W‚Ä≤S_{1}^{\prime}-S_{2}^{\prime}=W^{\prime}. Remarkably this can be done even if one of the two servers drops out and is therefore inaccessible. For example, if Server 111 drops out, then we can update the storage only at Server 222 to end up with S1‚Ä≤=S1=W+ZfragmentsS1‚Ä≤S1WZS_{1}^{\prime}=S_{1}=W+Z, and S2‚Ä≤=Z‚àíŒîfragmentsS2‚Ä≤ZŒîS_{2}^{\prime}=Z-\Delta, such that indeed S1‚Ä≤‚àíS2‚Ä≤=W‚Ä≤fragmentsS1‚Ä≤S2‚Ä≤W‚Ä≤S_{1}^{\prime}-S_{2}^{\prime}=W^{\prime} and the coding function is unchanged.

[S1‚Ä≤S2‚Ä≤]=[S1S2‚Ä≤]=[1101][W+ŒîZ‚àíŒî]=[1101][W‚Ä≤Z‚Ä≤].fragmentsmatrixfragmentsS1‚Ä≤fragmentsS2‚Ä≤matrixfragmentsS1fragmentsS2‚Ä≤matrix1101matrixfragmentsWŒîfragmentsZŒîmatrix1101matrixfragmentsW‚Ä≤fragmentsZ‚Ä≤.\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}S_{1}^{\prime}\\ S_{2}^{\prime}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}S_{1}\\ S_{2}^{\prime}\end{bmatrix}={\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\ 0&1\end{bmatrix}}\begin{bmatrix}W+\Delta\\ Z-\Delta\end{bmatrix}={\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\ 0&1\end{bmatrix}}\begin{bmatrix}W^{\prime}\\ Z^{\prime}\end{bmatrix}. (20)

Similarly, if Server 222 drops out, then we can update the storage only at Server 111 to end up with S1‚Ä≤=W+Œî+ZfragmentsS1‚Ä≤WŒîZS_{1}^{\prime}=W+\Delta+Z, and S2‚Ä≤=S2=ZfragmentsS2‚Ä≤S2ZS_{2}^{\prime}=S_{2}=Z, such that we still have S1‚Ä≤‚àíS2‚Ä≤=W‚Ä≤fragmentsS1‚Ä≤S2‚Ä≤W‚Ä≤S_{1}^{\prime}-S_{2}^{\prime}=W^{\prime} and the coding function is unchanged.

[S1‚Ä≤S2‚Ä≤]=[S1‚Ä≤S2]=[1101][W+ŒîZ]=[1101][W‚Ä≤Z].fragmentsmatrixfragmentsS1‚Ä≤fragmentsS2‚Ä≤matrixfragmentsS1‚Ä≤fragmentsS2matrix1101matrixfragmentsWŒîùëçmatrix1101matrixfragmentsW‚Ä≤ùëç.\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}S_{1}^{\prime}\\ S_{2}^{\prime}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}S_{1}^{\prime}\\ S_{2}\end{bmatrix}={\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\ 0&1\end{bmatrix}}\begin{bmatrix}W+\Delta\\ Z\end{bmatrix}={\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\ 0&1\end{bmatrix}}\begin{bmatrix}W^{\prime}\\ Z\end{bmatrix}. (21)

This, intuitively, is how the paradox is resolved, and a distributed database is fully updated even when it is only partially accessible. Note that the realization of the ‚Äúnoise‚Äù symbol is different for various realizations of the dropout servers, Z‚Ä≤‚â†ZfragmentsZ‚Ä≤ZZ^{\prime}\neq Z.

While the toy example conveys a key idea, the generalization of this idea to the ACSA-RW scheme is rather non-trivial. Let us shed some light on this generalization, which is made possible by the construction of an ‚ÄúACSA null-shaper‚Äù, see Definition 8. Specifically, by carefully placing nulls of the CSA code polynomial in the update equation, the storage of the write-dropout servers in ùíÆw(t)fragmentsSùë§fragments(t)\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)} is left unmodified. It is important to point out that the storage structure (i.e., ACSA storage, see Definition 3) is preserved, just as the coding function is left unchanged in the toy example above. Let us demonstrate the idea with a minimal example where X=2,T=1,XŒî=0,N=4fragmentsX2,T1,XŒî0,N4X=2,T=1,X_{\Delta}=0,N=4. Let us define the following functions.

ùêí(Œ±)fragmentsS(Œ±)\displaystyle{\bf S}(\alpha) =ùêñ+Œ±ùêô1+Œ±2ùêô2,fragmentsWŒ±Z1Œ±2Z2,\displaystyle=\mathbf{W}+\alpha\mathbf{Z}_{1}+\alpha^{2}\mathbf{Z}_{2}, (22)
ùêê(Œ±)fragmentsQ(Œ±)\displaystyle{\bf Q}(\alpha) =ùêûK(Œ∏t)+Œ±ùêô‚Ä≤,fragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)Œ±Z‚Ä≤,\displaystyle=\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t})+\alpha\mathbf{Z}^{\prime}, (23)

where ùêñ=[W1,W2,‚ãØ,WK]fragmentsW[W1,W2,‚ãØ,Wùêæ]\mathbf{W}=[W_{1},W_{2},\cdots,W_{K}] is a K√ó1fragmentsK1K\times 1 vector of the KùêæK data (submodel) symbols, ùêô1,ùêô2,ùêô‚Ä≤fragmentsZ1,Z2,Z‚Ä≤\mathbf{Z}_{1},\mathbf{Z}_{2},\mathbf{Z}^{\prime} are uniformly and independently distributed noise vectors that are used to protect data security and the user‚Äôs privacy, respectively. Let Œ±1,Œ±2,Œ±3,Œ±4fragmentsŒ±1,Œ±2,Œ±3,Œ±4\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3},\alpha_{4} be 444 distinct non-zero elements from a finite field ùîΩqfragmentsFùëû\mathbb{F}_{q}. The storage at the 444 servers is ùêí(Œ±1)fragmentsS(Œ±1){\bf S}(\alpha_{1}), ùêí(Œ±2)fragmentsS(Œ±2){\bf S}(\alpha_{2}), ùêí(Œ±3)fragmentsS(Œ±3){\bf S}(\alpha_{3}), ùêí(Œ±4)fragmentsS(Œ±4){\bf S}(\alpha_{4}), respectively. Similarly, the read-queries for the 444 servers are ùêê(Œ±1)fragmentsQ(Œ±1){\bf Q}(\alpha_{1}), ùêê(Œ±2)fragmentsQ(Œ±2){\bf Q}(\alpha_{2}), ùêê(Œ±3)fragmentsQ(Œ±3){\bf Q}(\alpha_{3}), ùêê(Œ±4)fragmentsQ(Œ±4){\bf Q}(\alpha_{4}), respectively. We note that the storage vectors and the query vectors can be viewed as secret sharings of ùêñùêñ{\bf W} and ùêûK(Œ∏t)fragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°){\bf e}_{K}(\theta_{t}) vectors with threshold of X=2fragmentsX2X=2 and T=1fragmentsT1T=1, respectively. Let us define the function Œ©(Œ±)=(Œ±1‚àíŒ±)/Œ±1fragmentsŒ©(Œ±)(Œ±1Œ±)Œ±1\Omega(\alpha)=(\alpha_{1}-\alpha)/\alpha_{1}, which is referred to as ACSA null-shaper, and consider the following update equation.

ùêí‚Ä≤(Œ±)=ùêí(Œ±)+Œ©(Œ±)Œîtùêê(Œ±).fragmentsS‚Ä≤(Œ±)S(Œ±)Œ©(Œ±)Œîùë°Q(Œ±).\displaystyle{\bf S}^{\prime}(\alpha)={\bf S}(\alpha)+\Omega(\alpha)\Delta_{t}{\bf Q}(\alpha). (24)

Note that ACSA null-shaper does not affect the storage structure because X=2>T=1fragmentsX2T1X=2>T=1. The idea illustrated in this minimal example indeed generalizes to the full ACSA-RW scheme, see Section IV for details.

On the other hand, our construction guarantees information theoretic privacy for an unlimited number of updates, without extra storage overhead. Furthermore, we note that the normalized download cost achieved by the construction in [Kim_Lee_FSL] cannot be less than 222, whereas ACSA-RW achieves download cost of less than 222 with large enough NùëÅN. For the asymptotic setting L/K‚Üí‚àûfragmentsLK‚ÜíL/K\rightarrow\infty, the upload cost101010In [Kim_Lee_FSL] the achieved upload cost is NLK+L+KfragmentsNLKLKNLK+L+K. The lower bound of upload cost of XSTPFSL is characterized in [Kim_Lee_FSL] as NKfragmentsNKNK. However, our construction of ACSA-RW shows that it is possible to do better.111111It is assumed in [Kim_Lee_FSL] that for the desired submodel, the user uploads LùêøL symbols for the update, while for other submodels, the user should also upload (K‚àí1)Lfragments(K1)L(K-1)L symbols to guarantee the privacy. However, it turns out that the uploaded symbols for the update of the desired submodel and the symbols for the purpose of guaranteeing the privacy do not have to be independent. In particular, for the asymptotic setting K‚Üí‚àû,L/K‚Üí‚àûfragmentsK‚Üí,LK‚ÜíK\rightarrow\infty,L/K\rightarrow\infty, the upload cost of less than NùëÅN is achievable by the ACSA-RW scheme.

III-A8 Comparison with [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub]

Let us also briefly review the 444-server information-theoretic DORAM construction in [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub] to see how our ACSA-RW scheme improves upon it. Note that the setting considered in [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub] is a special case of our problem where X=1,T=1,XŒî=0,Kc=1fragmentsX1,T1,XŒî0,Kùëê1X=1,T=1,X_{\Delta}=0,K_{c}=1 and |ùíÆw(t)|=|ùíÆr(t)|=0fragments|Sùë§fragments(t)||Sùëüfragments(t)|0|\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}|=|\mathcal{S}_{r}^{(t)}|=0 for all t‚àà‚ÑïfragmentstNt\in\mathbb{N}. First, we note that in the asymptotic setting L/K‚Üí‚àûfragmentsLK‚ÜíL/K\rightarrow\infty, the upload cost achieved by the ACSA-RW is the same as that in [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub]. Therefore, for this comparison we focus on the read phase and the download cost. Specifically, the information-theoretic DORAM construction in [Kushilevitz_DORAM_Sub] partitions the four servers into two groups, each of which consists of 222 servers. For the retrieval phase, the first group emulates a 222-server PIR, storing the KùêæK submodels secured with additive random noise, i.e., ùêñ+ùêôfragmentsWZ\mathbf{W}+\mathbf{Z}. The second group emulates another 222-server PIR storing the random noise ùêôùêô\mathbf{Z}. To retrieve the desired submodel privately, the user exploits a PIR scheme to retrieve the desired secured submodel, as well as the corresponding random noise. Therefore, with capacity-achieving PIR schemes, the download cost is 444 (for large KùêæK). On the other hand, our ACSA-RW scheme avoids the partitioning of the servers and improves the download cost by jointly exploiting all 444 servers. Remarkably, with the idea of cross-subspace alignment, out of the 444 downloaded symbols, the interference symbols align within 222 dimensions, leaving 222 dimensions interference-free for the desired symbols, and consequently, the asymptotically optimal download cost of 222 is achievable. Lastly, the ACSA-RW scheme also generalizes efficiently to arbitrary numbers of servers.

III-A9 On the Assumption L‚â´K‚â´1fragmentsLmuch-greater-thanKmuch-greater-than1L\gg K\gg 1 for FSL

Suppose we have N=6fragmentsN6N=6 distributed servers, we require security and privacy levels of XŒî=T=1,X=3fragmentsXŒîT1,X3X_{\Delta}=T=1,X=3. Let us set Kc=1fragmentsKùëê1K_{c}=1, and we operate over ùîΩ8fragmentsF8\mathbb{F}_{8}. Consider an e-commerce recommendation application similar to what is studied in [SFSM], where a global model with a total of 3,500,000fragments3,500,0003,500,000 symbols (from ùîΩ8fragmentsF8\mathbb{F}_{8}) is partitioned into K=50fragmentsK50K=50 submodels. Each of the submodels is comprised of L=70,000fragmentsL70,000L=70,000 symbols. Note that L‚â´K‚â´1fragmentsLmuch-greater-thanKmuch-greater-than1L\gg K\gg 1. Let us assume that there are no dropout servers for some t‚àà‚ÑïfragmentstNt\in\mathbb{N}. Now according to Lemma 2, the normalized upload cost achieved by the ACSA-RW scheme is Ut=6√ó35000+6√ó2√ó5070,000‚âà3.00857fragmentsUùë°fragments6350006250fragments70,0003.00857U_{t}=\frac{6\times 35000+6\times 2\times 50}{70,000}\approx 3.00857. Evidently, the asymptotic limits K‚Üí‚àû,L/K‚Üí‚àûfragmentsK‚Üí,LK‚ÜíK\rightarrow\infty,L/K\rightarrow\infty are fairly accurate for this non-asymptotic setting. For this particular example, the upload cost is increased by only 0.29%fragments0.29percent0.29\% compared to the asymptotic limit. On the other hand, the download cost is increased by only 1.4√ó10‚àí22%fragments1.410fragments22percent1.4\times 10^{-22}\% compared to the lower bound (evaluated for K=50fragmentsK50K=50) from [Jia_Sun_Jafar_XSTPIR].

IV Proof of Theorem 1

For all t‚àà‚ÑïfragmentstNt\in\mathbb{N}, we require that the number of read and write dropout servers is less than the corresponding threshold values, 0‚â§|ùíÆr(t)|<Srthreshfragments0|Sùëüfragments(t)|Sùëüthresh0\leq|\mathcal{S}_{r}^{(t)}|<S_{r}^{\text{thresh}} and 0‚â§|ùíÆw(t)|<Swthreshfragments0|Sùë§fragments(t)|Sùë§thresh0\leq|\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}|<S_{w}^{\text{thresh}}. Definition 1.

(Pole Assignment) If Œº‚â•KcfragmentsŒºKùëê\mu\geq K_{c}, let us define the Œº√óKcfragmentsŒºKùëê\mu\times K_{c} matrix ùêÖùêÖ\mathbf{F} to be the first KcfragmentsKùëêK_{c} columns of the following Œº√óŒºfragmentsŒºŒº\mu\times\mu matrix.

[f~1f~Œº‚Ä¶f~3f~2f~2f~1f~Œºf~3‚ãÆf~2f~1‚ã±‚ãÆf~Œº‚àí1‚ã±‚ã±f~Œºf~Œºf~Œº‚àí1‚Ä¶f~2f~1].fragmentsmatrixfragments~ùëì1fragments~ùëìùúá‚Ä¶fragments~ùëì3fragments~ùëì2fragments~ùëì2fragments~ùëì1fragments~ùëìùúámissing-subexpressionfragments~ùëì3‚ãÆfragments~ùëì2fragments~ùëì1‚ã±‚ãÆfragments~ùëìfragmentsŒº1missing-subexpression‚ã±‚ã±fragments~ùëìùúáfragments~ùëìùúáfragments~ùëìfragmentsŒº1‚Ä¶fragments~ùëì2fragments~ùëì1.\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}\widetilde{f}_{1}&\widetilde{f}_{\mu}&\dots&\widetilde{f}_{3}&\widetilde{f}_{2}\\ \widetilde{f}_{2}&\widetilde{f}_{1}&\widetilde{f}_{\mu}&&\widetilde{f}_{3}\\ \vdots&\widetilde{f}_{2}&\widetilde{f}_{1}&\ddots&\vdots\\ \widetilde{f}_{\mu-1}&&\ddots&\ddots&\widetilde{f}_{\mu}\\ \widetilde{f}_{\mu}&\widetilde{f}_{\mu-1}&\dots&\widetilde{f}_{2}&\widetilde{f}_{1}\end{bmatrix}. Definition 2.

(Noise Assignment) For all t‚àà‚Ñï,i‚àà[Kc],s‚àà[T]fragmentstN,i[Kùëê],s[T]t\in\mathbb{N},i\in[K_{c}],s\in[T], let us define

=(ùêô~1,i,s(t),ùêô~2,i,s(t),‚ãØ,ùêô~Œº,i,s(t),ùêô~1,i,s(t),ùêô~2,i,s(t),‚ãØ,ùêô~Œº,i,s(t),‚ãØ,ùêô~1,i,s(t),ùêô~2,i,s(t),‚ãØ,ùêô~Œº,i,s(t)),fragments(~ùêôfragments1,i,sfragments(t),~ùêôfragments2,i,sfragments(t),‚ãØ,~ùêôfragmentsŒº,i,sfragments(t),~ùêôfragments1,i,sfragments(t),~ùêôfragments2,i,sfragments(t),‚ãØ,~ùêôfragmentsŒº,i,sfragments(t),‚ãØ,~ùêôfragments1,i,sfragments(t),~ùêôfragments2,i,sfragments(t),‚ãØ,~ùêôfragmentsŒº,i,sfragments(t)),\displaystyle=\left(\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{1,i,s}^{(t)},\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{2,i,s}^{(t)},\cdots,\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{\mu,i,s}^{(t)},\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{1,i,s}^{(t)},\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{2,i,s}^{(t)},\cdots,\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{\mu,i,s}^{(t)},\cdots,\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{1,i,s}^{(t)},\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{2,i,s}^{(t)},\cdots,\widetilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{\mu,i,s}^{(t)}\right), (41)

Definition 3.

(ACSA Storage) For any t‚àà‚Ñ§‚àófragmentstZt\in\mathbb{Z}^{*}, the storage at the NùëÅN servers is said to form an ACSA storage if for all n‚àà[N]fragmentsn[N]n\in[N], ùêín(t)fragmentsSùëõfragments(t)\mathbf{S}_{n}^{(t)} has the following form.

ùêín(t)=[‚àëi‚àà[Kc]1Œ±n‚àíf1,iùêñÀô(t)1,i+‚àëx‚àà[X]Œ±nx‚àí1ùêôÀô1,x(t)‚àëi‚àà[Kc]1Œ±n‚àíf2,iùêñÀô(t)2,i+‚àëx‚àà[X]Œ±nx‚àí1ùêôÀô2,x(t)‚ãÆ‚àëi‚àà[Kc]1Œ±n‚àífJ,iùêñÀô(t)J,i+‚àëx‚àà[X]Œ±nx‚àí1ùêôÀôJ,x(t)].fragmentsSùëõfragments(t)matrixfragmentsfragmentsi[Kùëê]1fragmentsŒ±ùëõffragments1,iÀôùêñfragments(t)fragments1,ifragmentsx[X]Œ±ùëõfragmentsx1Àôùêôfragments1,xfragments(t)fragmentsfragmentsi[Kùëê]1fragmentsŒ±ùëõffragments2,iÀôùêñfragments(t)fragments2,ifragmentsx[X]Œ±ùëõfragmentsx1Àôùêôfragments2,xfragments(t)‚ãÆfragmentsfragmentsi[Kùëê]1fragmentsŒ±ùëõffragmentsJ,iÀôùêñfragments(t)fragmentsJ,ifragmentsx[X]Œ±ùëõfragmentsx1ÀôùêôfragmentsJ,xfragments(t).\displaystyle\mathbf{S}_{n}^{(t)}=\begin{bmatrix}\sum_{i\in[K_{c}]}\frac{1}{\alpha_{n}-f_{1,i}}\dot{\mathbf{W}}^{(t)}_{1,i}+\sum_{x\in[X]}\alpha_{n}^{x-1}\dot{\mathbf{Z}}_{1,x}^{(t)}\\ \sum_{i\in[K_{c}]}\frac{1}{\alpha_{n}-f_{2,i}}\dot{\mathbf{W}}^{(t)}_{2,i}+\sum_{x\in[X]}\alpha_{n}^{x-1}\dot{\mathbf{Z}}_{2,x}^{(t)}\\ \vdots\\ \sum_{i\in[K_{c}]}\frac{1}{\alpha_{n}-f_{J,i}}\dot{\mathbf{W}}^{(t)}_{J,i}+\sum_{x\in[X]}\alpha_{n}^{x-1}\dot{\mathbf{Z}}_{J,x}^{(t)}\end{bmatrix}. (42)

Note that XùëãX i.i.d. uniform random noise terms are MDS coded to guarantee the XùëãX-security.

Definition 4.

(ACSA Query) For any t‚àà‚ÑïfragmentstNt\in\mathbb{N}, the read-queries (Qn(t,Œ∏t))n‚àà[N]fragments(Qùëõfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°))fragmentsn[N]\left(Q_{n}^{(t,\theta_{t})}\right)_{n\in[N]} by User tùë°t for the NùëÅN servers are said to form an ACSA query if for all n‚àà[N]fragmentsn[N]n\in[N], we have

Qn(t,Œ∏t)=(ùêê(t,Œ∏t)n,1,ùêê(t,Œ∏t)n,2,‚ãØ,ùêê(t,Œ∏t)n,Kc),fragmentsQùëõfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)(Qfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)fragmentsn,1,Qfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)fragmentsn,2,‚ãØ,Qfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)fragmentsn,Kùëê),\displaystyle Q_{n}^{(t,\theta_{t})}=\left(\mathbf{Q}^{(t,\theta_{t})}_{n,1},\mathbf{Q}^{(t,\theta_{t})}_{n,2},\cdots,\mathbf{Q}^{(t,\theta_{t})}_{n,K_{c}}\right), (43)

where for all i‚àà[Kc]fragmentsi[Kùëê]i\in[K_{c}]

ùêê(t,Œ∏t)n,i=[ùêûK(Œ∏t)+(Œ±n‚àíf1,i)‚àës‚àà[T]Œ±ns‚àí1ùêô¬®1,i,s(t)ùêûK(Œ∏t)+(Œ±n‚àíf2,i)‚àës‚àà[T]Œ±ns‚àí1ùêô¬®2,i,s(t)‚ãÆùêûK(Œ∏t)+(Œ±n‚àífJ,i)‚àës‚àà[T]Œ±ns‚àí1ùêô¬®J,i,s(t)].fragmentsQfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)fragmentsn,imatrixfragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)(Œ±ùëõffragments1,i)fragmentss[T]Œ±ùëõfragmentss1¬®ùêôfragments1,i,sfragments(t)fragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)(Œ±ùëõffragments2,i)fragmentss[T]Œ±ùëõfragmentss1¬®ùêôfragments2,i,sfragments(t)‚ãÆfragmentseùêæ(Œ∏ùë°)(Œ±ùëõffragmentsJ,i)fragmentss[T]Œ±ùëõfragmentss1¬®ùêôfragmentsJ,i,sfragments(t).\displaystyle\mathbf{Q}^{(t,\theta_{t})}_{n,i}=\begin{bmatrix}\mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t})+(\alpha_{n}-f_{1,i})\sum_{s\in[T]}\alpha_{n}^{s-1}\ddot{\mathbf{Z}}_{1,i,s}^{(t)}\\ \mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t})+(\alpha_{n}-f_{2,i})\sum_{s\in[T]}\alpha_{n}^{s-1}\ddot{\mathbf{Z}}_{2,i,s}^{(t)}\\ \vdots\\ \mathbf{e}_{K}(\theta_{t})+(\alpha_{n}-f_{J,i})\sum_{s\in[T]}\alpha_{n}^{s-1}\ddot{\mathbf{Z}}_{J,i,s}^{(t)}\end{bmatrix}. (44)

Note that for all t‚àà‚Ñï,n‚àà[N]fragmentstN,n[N]t\in\mathbb{N},n\in[N], H(Qn(t,Œ∏t))=ŒºKcKfragmentsH(Qùëõfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°))ŒºKùëêKH\left(Q_{n}^{(t,\theta_{t})}\right)=\mu K_{c}K in qùëûq-ary units, because according to Definition 1 and Definition 2, for all i‚àà[Kc]fragmentsi[Kùëê]i\in[K_{c}], ùêên,i(t,Œ∏t)fragmentsQfragmentsn,ifragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)\mathbf{Q}_{n,i}^{(t,\theta_{t})} is uniquely determined by its first ŒºKfragmentsŒºK\mu K entries (the rest are replicas). Also note that TùëáT i.i.d. uniform random noise terms are MDS coded to guarantee the TùëáT-privacy.

Remark 1.

Indeed, the fact that ùêên,i(t,Œ∏t)fragmentsQfragmentsn,ifragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)\mathbf{Q}_{n,i}^{(t,\theta_{t})} is uniquely determined by its first ŒºKfragmentsŒºK\mu K entries is jointly guaranteed by the cyclic structures of pole assignment and noise assignment, i.e., Definition 1 and Definition 2. These cyclic structures are important in terms of minimizing the entropy of ACSA queries, so that it does not scale with the number of symbols LùêøL.

Definition 5.

Also note that XŒîfragmentsXŒîX_{\Delta} MDS coded i.i.d. uniform noise terms are used to guarantee the XŒîfragmentsXŒîX_{\Delta}-security.

Definition 6.

(49)

Note that the ACSA packer is a constant since |ùíÆr(t)|fragments|Sùëüfragments(t)||\mathcal{S}_{r}^{(t)}| is globally known.

Definition 7.

(ACSA Unpacker) For all t‚àà‚Ñï,n‚àà[N]fragmentstN,n[N]t\in\mathbb{N},n\in[N], the ACSA Unpacker is defined as follows.

Œ•n(t)=(ùöºn,1(t),ùöºn,2(t),‚ãØ,ùöºn,Kc(t)),fragmentsŒ•ùëõfragments(t)(Œ•fragmentsn,1fragments(t),Œ•fragmentsn,2fragments(t),‚ãØ,Œ•fragmentsn,Kùëêfragments(t)),\displaystyle\Upsilon_{n}^{(t)}=\left(\mathbf{\Upsilon}_{n,1}^{(t)},\mathbf{\Upsilon}_{n,2}^{(t)},\cdots,\mathbf{\Upsilon}_{n,K_{c}}^{(t)}\right), (50)

where for all i‚àà[Kc]fragmentsi[Kùëê]i\in[K_{c}],

ùöºn,i(t)=diag((‚àèj‚àà‚Ñ±1(t)(Œ±n‚àífj,i)‚àèj‚àà‚Ñ±1(t)(f1,i‚àífj,i))ùêàK,‚ãØ,(‚àèj‚àà‚Ñ±J(t)(Œ±n‚àífj,i)‚àèj‚àà‚Ñ±J(t)(fJ,i‚àífj,i))ùêàK),fragmentsŒ•fragmentsn,ifragments(t)diag((fragmentsproductfragmentsjF1fragments(t)(Œ±ùëõffragmentsj,i)fragmentsproductfragmentsjF1fragments(t)(ffragments1,iffragmentsj,i))Iùêæ,‚ãØ,(fragmentsproductfragmentsjFùêΩfragments(t)(Œ±ùëõffragmentsj,i)fragmentsproductfragmentsjFùêΩfragments(t)(ffragmentsJ,iffragmentsj,i))Iùêæ),\displaystyle\mathbf{\Upsilon}_{n,i}^{(t)}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\left(\frac{\prod_{j\in\mathcal{F}_{1}^{(t)}}(\alpha_{n}-f_{j,i})}{\prod_{j\in\mathcal{F}_{1}^{(t)}}(f_{1,i}-f_{j,i})}\right)\mathbf{I}_{K},\cdots,\left(\frac{\prod_{j\in\mathcal{F}_{J}^{(t)}}(\alpha_{n}-f_{j,i})}{\prod_{j\in\mathcal{F}_{J}^{(t)}}(f_{J,i}-f_{j,i})}\right)\mathbf{I}_{K}\right), (51)

where for all j‚àà[J]fragmentsj[J]j\in[J], we define ‚Ñ±j=[(‚åàj/Rw(t)‚åâ‚àí1)Rw(t)+1:‚åàj/Rw(t)‚åâRw(t)]‚àñ{j}fragmentsFùëó[(‚åàjRùë§fragments(t)‚åâ1)Rùë§fragments(t)1:‚åàjRùë§fragments(t)‚åâRùë§fragments(t)]{j}\mathcal{F}_{j}=\left[\left(\left\lceil j/R_{w}^{(t)}\right\rceil-1\right)R_{w}^{(t)}+1:\left\lceil j/R_{w}^{(t)}\right\rceil R_{w}^{(t)}\right]\setminus\{j\}. Note that the ACSA unpacker is a constant since |ùíÆw(t)|fragments|Sùë§fragments(t)||\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}| is globally known.

Remark 2.

As noted at the beginning of the proof, private read and write operations consists of Kc#r(t)fragmentsKùëê#ùëüfragments(t)K_{c}\#_{r}^{(t)} and Kc#w(t)fragmentsKùëê#ùë§fragments(t)K_{c}\#_{w}^{(t)} sub-operations, and for each sub-operation, Rr(t)fragmentsRùëüfragments(t)R_{r}^{(t)} and Rw(t)fragmentsRùë§fragments(t)R_{w}^{(t)} symbols of the desired submodel are retrieved and updated respectively. This is respectively made possible by the constructions of ACSA Packer and Unpacker. For private read, by ACSA Packer, in each sub-operation Rr(t)fragmentsRùëüfragments(t)R_{r}^{(t)} symbols of the desired submodel are ‚Äúpacked‚Äù into a Cauchy-Vandermonde structured answer string for best download efficiency, where Cauchy terms carry desired symbols and interference symbols are aligned along Vandermonde terms. Recoverability of the desired symbols is guaranteed by the invertibility of Cauchy-Vandermonde matrices (see, e.g., [Gasca_Martinez_Muhlbach]). On the other hand, ACSA Increment (Definition 5) can be viewed as a bunch of Cauchy-Vandermonde structured codewords, and in each codeword, a total of Rw(t)fragmentsRùë§fragments(t)R_{w}^{(t)} symbols are ‚Äúpacked‚Äù together for best upload efficiency. To correctly perform private write, each of the codewords is ‚Äúunpacked‚Äù by the ACSA Unpacker to produce Rw(t)fragmentsRùë§fragments(t)R_{w}^{(t)} codewords that individually carry different increment symbols to preserve the ACSA Storage structure (Definition 3).

Definition 8.

(ACSA Null-shaper) For all t‚àà‚Ñï,n‚àà[N]fragmentstN,n[N]t\in\mathbb{N},n\in[N], the ACSA null-shaper is defined as follows.

Œ©(t)=(ùõÄn,1(t),ùõÄn,2(t),‚ãØ,ùõÄn,Kc(t)),fragmentsŒ©fragments(t)(Œ©fragmentsn,1fragments(t),Œ©fragmentsn,2fragments(t),‚ãØ,Œ©fragmentsn,Kùëêfragments(t)),\displaystyle\Omega^{(t)}=\left(\mathbf{\Omega}_{n,1}^{(t)},\mathbf{\Omega}_{n,2}^{(t)},\cdots,\mathbf{\Omega}_{n,K_{c}}^{(t)}\right), (52)

where for all i‚àà[Kc]fragmentsi[Kùëê]i\in[K_{c}],

ùõÄn,i(t)=diag((‚àèm‚ààùíÆw(t)(Œ±n‚àíŒ±m)‚àèm‚ààùíÆw(t)(f1,i‚àíŒ±m))ùêàK,‚ãØ,(‚àèm‚ààùíÆw(t)(Œ±n‚àíŒ±m)‚àèm‚ààùíÆw(t)(fJ,i‚àíŒ±m))ùêàK).fragmentsŒ©fragmentsn,ifragments(t)diag((fragmentsproductfragmentsmSùë§fragments(t)(Œ±ùëõŒ±ùëö)fragmentsproductfragmentsmSùë§fragments(t)(ffragments1,iŒ±ùëö))Iùêæ,‚ãØ,(fragmentsproductfragmentsmSùë§fragments(t)(Œ±ùëõŒ±ùëö)fragmentsproductfragmentsmSùë§fragments(t)(ffragmentsJ,iŒ±ùëö))Iùêæ).\displaystyle\mathbf{\Omega}_{n,i}^{(t)}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\left(\frac{\prod_{m\in\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}}(\alpha_{n}-\alpha_{m})}{\prod_{m\in\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}}(f_{1,i}-\alpha_{m})}\right)\mathbf{I}_{K},\cdots,\left(\frac{\prod_{m\in\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}}(\alpha_{n}-\alpha_{m})}{\prod_{m\in\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}}(f_{J,i}-\alpha_{m})}\right)\mathbf{I}_{K}\right). (53)

Note that for all n‚ààùíÆw(t)fragmentsnSùë§fragments(t)n\in\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)}, we have ùõÄn=ùüéfragmentsŒ©ùëõ0\mathbf{\Omega}_{n}=\mathbf{0}. Besides, the ACSA null-shaper is a constant since ùíÆw(t)fragmentsSùë§fragments(t)\mathcal{S}_{w}^{(t)} is globally known.

Definition 9.

(ACSA-RW Scheme) The initial storage at the NùëÅN servers is the ACSA storage at time 00, i.e., (ùêín(0))n‚àà[N]fragments(Sùëõfragments(0))fragmentsn[N]\left(\mathbf{S}_{n}^{(0)}\right)_{n\in[N]}. At time t,t‚àà‚Ñïfragmentst,tNt,t\in\mathbb{N}, in the read phase, the user uploads the ACSA query for the NùëÅN servers and retrieves the desired submodel ùêñ(t‚àí1)Œ∏tfragmentsWfragments(t1)fragmentsŒ∏ùë°\mathbf{W}^{(t-1)}_{\theta_{t}} from the answers returned by the servers n,n‚ààùíÆ¬Ør(t)fragmentsn,n¬ØùíÆùëüfragments(t)n,n\in\overline{\mathcal{S}}_{r}^{(t)}, which are constructed as follows.

An(t,Œ∏t)=((ùêín(t‚àí1))ùñ≥ùöµn,‚Ñì,i(t)ùêên,i(t,Œ∏t))‚Ñì‚àà[#r(t)],i‚àà[Kc],n‚ààùíÆ¬Ør(t).fragmentsAùëõfragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)((Sùëõfragments(t1))ùñ≥Œûfragmentsn,‚Ñì,ifragments(t)Qfragmentsn,ifragments(t,Œ∏ùë°))fragments‚Ñì[#ùëüfragments(t)],i[Kùëê],n¬ØùíÆùëüfragments(t).\displaystyle A_{n}^{(t,\theta_{t})}=\left(\left(\mathbf{S}_{n}^{(t-1)}\right)^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{\Xi}_{n,\ell,i}^{(t)}\mathbf{Q}_{n,i}^{(t,\theta_{t})}\right)_{\ell\in[\#_{r}^{(t)}],i\in[K_{c}]},n\in\overline{\mathcal{S}}_{r}^{(t)}. (54)

In the update phase, the user uploads the ACSA increment for the servers n,n‚ààùíÆ¬Øw(t)fragmentsn,n¬ØùíÆùë§fragments(t)n,n\in\overline{\mathcal{S}}_{w}^{(t)}, and each of the servers updates its storage according to the following equation.

ùêín(t)fragmentsSùëõfragments(t)\displaystyle\mathbf{S}_{n}^{(t)} =ùêín(t‚àí1)+‚àëi‚àà[Kc]ùõÄn,i(t)ùöºn,i(t)ùêèn,i(t,Œ∏t)ùêên,i(t,Œ∏t),n‚ààùíÆ¬Øw(t).fragmentsSùëõfragments(t1)fragmentsi[Kùëê]Œ©fragmentsn,ifragments(t)Œ•fragmentsn,ifragments(t)Pfragmentsn,ifragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)Qfragmentsn,ifragments(t,Œ∏ùë°),n¬ØùíÆùë§fragments(t).\displaystyle=\mathbf{S}_{n}^{(t-1)}+\sum_{i\in[K_{c}]}\mathbf{\Omega}_{n,i}^{(t)}\mathbf{\Upsilon}_{n,i}^{(t)}\mathbf{P}_{n,i}^{(t,\theta_{t})}\mathbf{Q}_{n,i}^{(t,\theta_{t})},n\in\overline{\mathcal{S}}_{w}^{(t)}. (55)

Now let us prove the correctness, privacy and security of the ACSA-RW scheme. To proceed, we need the following lemmas.

Lemma 1.

At any time t,t‚àà‚Ñïfragmentst,tNt,t\in\mathbb{N}, User tùë°t retrieves the desired submodel ùêñŒ∏t(t‚àí1)fragmentsWfragmentsŒ∏ùë°fragments(t1)\mathbf{W}_{\theta_{t}}^{(t-1)} from the answers returned by the servers n,n‚ààùíÆ¬Ør(t)fragmentsn,n¬ØùíÆùëüfragments(t)n,n\in\overline{\mathcal{S}}_{r}^{(t)} according to the ACSA-RW scheme while guaranteeing TùëáT-privacy.

Proof.

Let us consider the answers returned by the servers n,n‚ààùíÆ¬Ør(t)fragmentsn,n¬ØùíÆùëüfragments(t)n,n\in\overline{\mathcal{S}}_{r}^{(t)} in (54). Note that for all ‚Ñì‚àà[#r(t)]fragments‚Ñì[#ùëüfragments(t)]\ell\in[\#_{r}^{(t)}], i‚àà[Kc]fragmentsi[Kùëê]i\in[K_{c}], we have

(ùêín(t‚àí1))ùñ≥ùöµn,‚Ñì,i(t)ùêên,i(t,Œ∏t)fragments(Sùëõfragments(t1))ùñ≥Œûfragmentsn,‚Ñì,ifragments(t)Qfragmentsn,ifragments(t,Œ∏ùë°)\displaystyle\left(\mathbf{S}_{n}^{(t-1)}\right)^{\mathsf{T}}\mathbf{\Xi}_{n,\ell,i}^{(t)}\mathbf{Q}_{n,i}^{(t,\theta_{t})}

This completes the proof of Lemma 1. ‚àé

Lemma 2.
